newsitem.title: ITALY: Prodi rules out decree for Stet watchdog.
newsitem.headline: Prodi rules out decree for Stet watchdog.

text.p: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said in a newspaper interview he was against passing a decree to create a watchdog authority for the telecoms sector, a necessary step for the privatisation of state telecoms holding Stet.
The government wants to sell off Stet by the end of next March but before the flotation can go ahead parliament must approve a bill setting up a sector watchdog authority.
The draft law is still stuck in parliament.
"I do not agree with creating the authority by decree because I fear the financial markets would not like a privatisation carried out like that," he told the financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore.
Government decrees cut through red tape and take immediate effect but lapse unless they are ratified by parliament and passed into law with a certain period.
The measures on the authority are currently before the upper house, the Senate. They must then return to the lower Chamber of Deputies.
"As long as the Authority is set up by December, the Stet sale will be carried out according to plan, otherwise we will lose credibility. But I am sure parliament will do its job," Prodi said.

Asked if the government aimed to resort to a golden share for the Stet sale, Prodi said a golden share would only be used "to guarantee that Stet did not pass into the control of foreign groups." If the golden share "became the means to move from a real privatisation to a false privatisation, then I am against it," he said.
After the Stet sale, the government's privatisation calendar envisaged the sale of motorway operator Autostrade, Prodi said.
As for the complete privatisation of energy group ENI, Prodi said "it will be fully privatised" but did not indicate any timetable.
"We must take into account the risks of blocking up the stock market and the fact that all major public enterprises have been sold bit by bit," he added.

For the second tranche of Eni shares currently on offer, Prodi said "we had considered a larger second tranche, of around 12-13 percent against the 8.75 percent decided, but the experts advised us against it."
